Article Title: 'No footage of shooter, gun not identified': Cops admit no leads yet in Brown University shooting; massive manhunt on
Article Text:
AP file photo

US: Deadly Shootout At Brown University; Shooter ‘Hiding Inside Campus’, Mega Hunt On After 2 Killed

What happened?

Massive manhunt on









Providence police said they still have no clear lead into the shooting reported at Brown University, hours after the incident, as questions were raised about what authorities and university officials knew in its aftermath.Officials said that no suspect is currently in custody, contradicting an earlier statement from the university that one person had been detained.During a press interaction, a reporter questioned the university president about the lack of information regarding what occurred inside the classroom where the shooting took place. The reporter pointed out that six hours had passed since the incident and asked how details might still have been unavailable.In response, Brown University President Christina H Paxson said she "did not know" the details of the shooting, as of yet.When asked whether there was video footage from inside the building during the shooting, Providence police said they do not possess any video that “depicts” the shooter so far.“I haven’t seen him on video inside that building,” an official said, addressing the press.Officials at the scene also could not provide information on how many people were inside the building or the reasons for their presence.Police have announced that they will release a video of the suspect.Two people were killed and nine others injured in a shooting on Saturday afternoon at Brown University’s Barus & Holley building in Providence, Rhode Island, officials confirmed.According to a Brown University Health spokesperson, of the nine injured, one is in stable condition, six are critical but stable, and another has been stabilized. The ninth victim sustained fragment injuries that are not considered life-threatening.The shooting was first reported around 4.00 pm (local time), prompting the university to send an alert instructing students and faculty to lock doors, silence phones, and remain hidden due to reports of an active shooter. Many students took refuge in their dorms, while others sought shelter in the basement of a popular tea shop.The shooting took place in a classroom inside Brown University’s Barus & Holley building, which houses the engineering and physics departments. Mayor Brett Smiley said finals were ongoing in the building at the time, but officials have not confirmed what was happening in the specific classroom where the incident occurred.Officials described the shooter as a male wearing all black, who fled from the Barus & Holley engineering and physics building on the Hope Street side, as cited by NBC News.Investigators have not yet determined how the shooter gained access to the first-floor classroom. While the building’s outer doors were unlocked, rooms used for final exams required badge access, the mayor noted. A law enforcement official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said authorities believe the shooter was armed with a handgun, as reported by AP.On Saturday night, the Brown University campus took on the appearance of a fortified zone as more than 400 law enforcement officers converged on the area. Some officers searched for the gunman, using flashlights to inspect parked cars.US President Donald Trump stated on social media that he had been briefed on the shooting and confirmed that the FBI was present at the scene.”Rhode Island governor Dan McKee said he had spoken with FBI Director Kash Patel and that local, state, and federal law enforcement officers were all actively searching for the gunman.“The unthinkable has happened,” McKee said. "Everyone is working under the same goal right now -- to keep everybody in that area safe, and also to pursue."Mayor Brett Smiley said a shelter-in-place order remains in effect and urged residents near the campus to stay indoors or avoid returning home until it is lifted. Streets that are usually busy on weekends were unusually quiet.
Article Summary: Two people were killed and nine others injured in a shooting on Saturday afternoon at Brown University’s Barus & Holley building in Providence, Rhode Island. Police have announced that they will release a video of the suspect. The shooting was first reported around 4.00 pm (local time), prompting the university to send an alert instructing students and faculty to lock doors, silence phones, and remain hidden.

Article Title: Chennai: YouTuber Savukku Shankar held after refusing to cooperate with cops, defying summons
Article Text:
YouTuber held for defying summons

CHENNAI: YouTuber Savukku Shankar was arrested on Saturday by the Adambakkam police after he refused to cooperate with an inquiry and remained locked inside a house on Pallavaram-Thoraipakkam Radial Road for nearly five hours, prompting officers to break open the door with assistance from the Tambaram fire and rescue services personnel.Police said Shankar had been summoned for questioning in a case registered at the Adambakkam police station, in which he and others were accused of assaulting a man and extorting ₹2 lakh at his office.A warrant had been issued last month after he failed to appear for the inquiry. Despite receiving the notice, he did not present himself before the police.A special team led by the Adambakkam assistant commissioner of police reached the residence on Saturday morning. When officers knocked, Shankar remained inside and told them he would open the door only after his lawyers arrived. Even after his lawyer reached the spot, he continued to keep the door locked, police said.After waiting outside the house for nearly five hours, the police called the Tambaram fire and rescue services. Fire personnel broke open the door, following which officers entered and arrested Shankar around 2.15pm.Police also conducted a search inside the premises and later took him to the Madipakkam police station for inquiry.Before his arrest, Shankar released a video from inside the locked house, informing viewers that he had already sent a written response to the police notice and describing the case as false.He told his audience that the complainant, film producer Purushothaman, did not visit his office and that the complaint was based on incorrect information. In the video, he also spoke about claims that Purushothaman accused him of assault, threats, and taking ₹2 lakh, besides demanding additional payment to remove online content.After completing formalities, including a medical examination at Government General Hospital, Shankar was produced before the IX Metropolitan Magistrate Court in Saidapet. Magistrate Anitha ordered him to be remanded in judicial custody for 14 days. An investigation is underway.
Article Summary: Savukku Shankar was arrested on Saturday by the Adambakkam police after he refused to cooperate with an inquiry. He remained locked inside a house for nearly five hours, prompting officers to break open the door with assistance from the Tambaram fire and rescue services personnel. Shankar had been summoned for questioning in a case in which he and others were accused of assaulting a man and extorting ₹2 lakh at his office.

Candace Goes Nuclear On Erika Kirk: 'Mean Girl With Bible' Hit By 'Meghan Markle Syndrome'

Erika Kirk accuses Candace Owens of profiting from conspiracy theories in viral CBS clip

Candace Owens' 9/11 style attack post resurfaces after Brown University shooting

Article Title: Candace Owens drops bombshell claim that Tyler Robinson did not act alone in Charlie Kirk killing as court case intensifies
Article Text:
Candace Owens is reigniting controversy surrounding the Charlie Kirk killing, challenging prosecutors' claims that Tyler Robinson acted alone. Robinson faces aggravated murder charges, and Owens asserts he did not pull the trigger, contradicting the state's case. The legal proceedings are under intense scrutiny, with the victim's widow urging transparency while condemning speculation.

'Execute Tomorrow...': Candace Owens Claims Charlie Kirk Sent Alarming Texts Before Assassination

Candace Owens' Tyler Robinson claims raise fresh doubts in Charlie Kirk case





Candace Owens has once again pushed herself to the center of a national firestorm, reviving questions that many believed were settled. As Tyler Robinson made his first in person appearance in a Utah courtroom, the legal case surrounding the killing of conservative activist Charlie Kirk took on a sharper political and media edge. What unfolded inside the courtroom was serious. What followed online was explosive.Robinson, a 22 year old Utah man, faces aggravated murder and several related charges tied to the September 10 shooting at Utah Valley University. Prosecutors maintain he acted alone. Owens disagrees. Her renewed claims have fueled debate across social media, cable news, and political circles, adding pressure to an already volatile case. As cameras rolled under strict court rules, the trial moved forward under intense public scrutiny.The courtroom scene itself was tightly controlled. Robinson appeared in civilian clothes, restrained but composed, smiling briefly toward family members as Judge Tony F. Graf Jr. emphasized the presumption of innocence. Outside the courtroom, however, the narrative fractured.Owens addressed the controversy directly on social media, dismissing online speculation based on courtroom footage.She rejected interpretations drawn from lip reading videos and facial expressions, calling those reports fictional. According to Owens, Robinson’s reaction in court had nothing to do with guilt or secret signals.She said Robinson and his attorney had just learned that their security vehicle had been involved in a minor crash, a situation she claimed had occurred before. Owens also challenged prosecutors to back up their case publicly. While she stated she believes Robinson was involved on September 10, she drew a clear line beyond that.Owens said she does not believe Robinson pulled the trigger and does not believe he acted alone. Her remarks directly contradict statements from prosecutors, who have said the evidence shows Robinson acted by himself. Article Title: ‘I am going to run and I love you’: Son updates mother as Brown University shooting unfolds — Audio surfaces

A chilling text message sent by a Brown University student to his mother during a mass shooting on campus has surfaced on social media, capturing the fear and chaos that unfolded at the Ivy League school during final exams.“Text I get from my son is that mom, there's a live shooting on campus, I'm going to run, I love you,” the mother of the student could be heard saying in the audio clip. Article Title: Several US senators challenge a rule that ended automatic extension of work permits for spouses of H-1Bs and others
Article Text:

Trump’s Massive Visa Crackdown: 85,000 Cancellations and Social-Media Scrutiny Hit Indians





A group of Democratic-party senators including Alex Padilla, member of the Senate Judiciary Immigration Sub-committee; Jacky Rosen and several others, have moved a resolution to reverse an ‘interim final rule’ recently issued by the US Department of Homeland Security (DHS). This rule, which came into force from Oct 30, ended automatic renewals of work permits for certain categories of legally authorised non-citizens including spouses of H-1B visa holders.As reported earlier by TOI, it meant that nearly a lakh Indian spouses (largely women) who held employment authorisation documents (EADs) would no longer be able to continue to work after their current EAD expired. They would need to wait until the US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) approved and renewed their EAD. The hitch: H-4 EAD holders can file renewal applications only up to 180 days before the expiration date, but USCIS typically takes a longer time to process the application. These senators point out that the interim final rule would impact nearly 87% of all pending renewals causing immense hardship.Prior to this amendment, an auto-extension of the EAD of up to 540 days was available. Thus, those who filed renewal applications on time could continue working while their applications were pending, a safeguard designed to prevent job losses caused by bureaucratic delays.With the safeguard withdrawn, many individuals face the prospect of losing their livelihoods simply because their renewals are stuck in processing queues that often stretch for months.This group of US senators have moved the resolution under the Congressional Review Act (CRA) – it enables a federal agency rule to be quickly overturned by passing a joint resolution of disapproval within a limited time after the rule is issued. Legal experts explain that generally a resolution under the CRA requires the President to sign off. But, Congress can attempt to override the President’s veto with a super-majority vote.By using the CRA, these senators are attempting a fast-track legislative reversal that would not only restore automatic extensions but also prevent the Trump administration from reintroducing a similar rule in the future without explicit Congressional approval.All hopes of those impacted are pinned on this resolution. “Donald Trump and Stephen Miller’s campaign to marginalize noncitizens working here legally is disrupting our entire national economy and devastating employers who rely on their contributions,” said Senator Padilla. “The administration’s self-defeating rule to deny automatic work permit extensions would force people who have already been vetted to lose their ability to keep working, causing unnecessary strain for immigrants and employers alike. This rule, which came into force from Oct 30, ended automatic renewals of work permits for certain categories of legally authorised non-citizens.
